en.value:
<p>Which ultimate factor led to Lionel&#39;s death?</p>

<p>Lionel could not be saved as&nbsp;</p>
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the most appropriate options out of the given ones. 

  1. Lionel was in a bad shape. He was bloodied and beaten. He was too weak to haul his poor, broken little body inside the house. By the time Nola saw him; his battered body had already lost too much blood. Lionel, the duck, died a few minutes later. 
  2. When Nola broke the news to her customers, they were devastated. One elderly gentleman was especially heart-broken. He used to feed Lionel a slice of bread or a biscuit which he kept in his pocket especially for the occasion. They would spend an hour every week like that, enjoying each other's company. When he heard about Lionel's death, the old man sat down on the same bench and let the tears run freely down his cheeks. Two weeks later, he was dead. 
  3. Nola also had to tell the children who used to play with Lionel on their way to school. Lionel waddled around them, muttering and letting them feel his soft white feathers while they waited for the bus. Some of the children made sympathy cards for Nola. She also received many condolences - a few from friends and many from strangers. It was only then that she realised how many friends Lionel had made; how many hearts he had touched. It seemed as if the whole town was mourning his death.

en.value: Richard Cory was dressed in:
en.comp:
Read the stanzas given below and answer the questions/complete the statements that follow by choosing the most appropriate options out of the given ones. 

(Richard Cory) was always quietly arrayed, 

And he was always human when he talked;

But still he fluttered pulses when he said,

"Good morning" and he glittered when he walked.

And he was rich - yes richer than a king - 

And admirably schooled in every grace:

In fine, we thought that he was every thing 

To make us wish that we were in his place.

So we worked and waited for the light,

And went without meat and cursed the bread;

And Richard Cory, one calm summer night,

Went home and put a bullet through his head.

en.value: To study the gorilla the scientists:
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions/ complete the statements that follow by choosing the most appropriate options from the given ones.

The gorilla is something of a paradox in the African scene. One thinks one knows him very well. For a hundred years or more he has been killed, captured and imprisoned in zoos. His bones have been mounted in natural history museums everywhere, and he has always exerted a strong fascination upon scientists and romantics alike. He is the stereotyped monster of the horror films and the adventure books, and an obvious (though not perhaps strictly scientific) link with our ancestral past.

Yet the fact is we know very little about gorillas. No really satisfactory photograph has ever been taken of one in a wild state, no zoologist, however intrepid, has been able to keep the animal under close and constant observation in the dark jungles in which it lives. Carl Akley, the American naturalist, led two expeditions to these volcanoes in the nineteen twenties, and now lies buried here among the animals he loved so well. But even he was unable to discover how long the gorilla lives or how or why he dies, nor was he able to define the exact social pattern of the family groups, or indicate the final extent of their intelligence. All this and many other things remain almost as much a mystery as they were when a French explorer first described the animal to the civilised world a century ago. The Abominable Snowman who haunts the imagination of climbers in the Himalayas is hardly more elusive. The little that is known about gorillas certainly makes you want to know a great deal more. Sir Julian Huxley has recorded that thrice in the London zoo he saw an eighteen-month-old specimen trace the outline of its own shadow with its finger.

options.value: <span style="">killed him and stuffed his body.</span>
<span style="">captured him and kept him in a zoo.</span>
<span style="">went close to him in his natural habitat.</span>

But even he was unable to discover how long the gorilla lives or how or why he dies, nor was he able to define the exact social pattern of the family groups, or indicate the final extent of their intelligence. All this and many other things remain almost as much a mystery as they were when a French explorer first described the animal to the civilised world a century ago. The Abominable Snowman who haunts the imagination of climbers in the Himalayas is hardly more elusive. The little that is known about gorillas certainly makes you want to know a great deal more. Sir Julian Huxley has recorded that thrice in the London zoo he saw an eighteen-month-old specimen trace the outline of its own shadow with its finger.

en.value: What is the urgent need today in villages?
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the questions / complete the statements that follow by choosing the most appropriate options out of the given ones.

Motivations for ruralism in underdeveloped countries are understandably different from those in developed countries. There, it is a sheer physical necessity for the very act of man's survival. In the third world countries, which are predominantly rural, the only level that can lift human life above its present sub-human level, is rural development. Rural life in such countries has been stagnating for centuries on end. Nothing worthwhile has been done to ameliorate the condition of the rural population which is only slightly different from that of their quadruped counterparts. Ignorance, ill health and poverty have become synonymous with rural life in the undeveloped and underdeveloped countries. But the worst tragedy is that the concerned human populations have taken this state of affairs for granted, as something unalterable, something for which there is no remedy. Every ray of hope has gone out of their lives. In such countries, Rural Development is the inevitable condition of any material or non-material advancement. As such, enlightened sections of all such countries have been taking ever growing interest in the question of Rural Development. This was also part of the legacy of their freedom struggle. In countries like India, it is well-known that attempts at Rural development were an inseparable part of the Independence Movement. Leaders like Gandhiji realized quite well that Real India lived in her stagnating villages. Cities, which were mostly the products of western colonialism, were just artificial show pieces. Even then, there were two worlds. The posh areas, where the affluent few, mostly the products and custodians of imperial interest lived, were little islands engulfed by the vast ocean of dirt, represented by the vast majority of people.

Cities were by no means unknown to India, but in ancient India, they were integral parts, organically related to the rest of the country and society. But modern cities are exotic centres of commercial and industrial exploitation. Cities in ancient India were the flowers of cultural and artistic excellence of the nation, modern cities are just parasites, preying on and debilitating the country.

en.value:
<p>Students from different home languages may find it difficult in English medium classrooms.</p>

<p>Which of the following activities will <u><strong>NOT</strong></u> help in providing initial support for this situation?</p>

options.value: <span style="">Building a word wall in the classroom with words in English and their possible equivalents in home languages</span>
<span style="">Creating heterogeneous groups of mixed English language proficiency</span>
<span style="">Using physical gestures for certain words and phrases while reading aloud</span>
<span style="">Weekly tasks of grammar based worksheets to be done at home by all students in class.</span>
<span style="">What do you think the main characters will do next?</span>
<span style="">What happened next in a similar story you read last year?</span>
<span style="">What clues does the story so far provide, on what will happen next?</span>
<span style="">What is the meaning of a plot of a story? Give an example.</span>

en.value:
<p>Desuggestopedia is sometimes used to teach English to students for whom it is not the home language.</p>

<p>Which of the following visualization exercises is an example of this method?</p>

options.value: <span style="">Teacher reads aloud a story and asks students to close their eyes and visualise the setting. After each paragraph, she picks a student to identify the setting and corrects any errors.</span>

<span style="">Working in pairs, one student reads part of the story aloud, the other visualises the setting and shares it, and vice versa. The first pair to complete this is rewarded by the teacher.</span>

<span style="">Teacher reads aloud a story and asks students to close their eyes and visualise the setting. After the read aloud, she asks students to share what they visualised and be as creative as possible.</span>

<span style="">Students work in groups of 3: The student assigned as &#39;reader&#39; reads a paragraph, the &#39;visualiser&#39; visualises the setting and shares it with the third who is assigned as &#39;note taker&#39;.</span>

en.value: Which of the following would require &#39;intensive listening&#39; the <u><strong>LEAST</strong></u>?

options.value: <span style="">Listening to a short audiobook on a specific topic and summarising its main idea.</span>
<span style="">Watching an English video with annotations that give definitions and example sentences for specific words.</span>
<span style="">Listening to a text translated from first language to English and see how individual words correspond.</span>
<span style="">Doing activities on a learning website where students convert sentences from one form to another and do self-checks.</span>
<span style="">both (i) and (ii) are examples of skimming</span>
<span style="">both (i) and (ii) are examples of scanning</span>

en.value: Which of the following is an example of a teacher trying to provide &#39;comprehensible input&#39; as per Krashen&#39;s hypothesis?

options.value: <span style="">Providing students with text of their own levels for reading practice</span>
<span style="">Sharing newspaper articles with students and asking them to read these aloud</span>
<span style="">Underlining important words in a passage and checking if students comprehend their meaning.</span>
<span style="">Providing students with texts slightly above their level</span>

en.value:
<p>A teacher gives the same text to whole class and asks students to identify the main idea. However, she highlights key words in the text, for students with lower comprehension skills.</p>

<p>Is this a good example of differentiation? Why/Why not?</p>

options.value: <span style="">No, because each student should be assigned a text that is at his or her learning level rather than the same one for the class.</span>
<span style="">Yes, because this is a simple way to support students at lower reading levels so that they can complete the given task.</span>
<span style="">No because it is unfair to students with good comprehension skills that others are getting support.</span>
<span style="">Yes, because the teacher has &#39;watered down&#39; the syllabus for students with weaker comprehension skills.</span>

en.value: Which of the following pedagogical methods follows a &#39;contextualised approach&#39; towards teaching the topic of <strong>reported speech</strong> in English Grammar?

options.value: <span style="">Explaining different rules of conversion from direct to reported speech with single-sentence examples.</span>
<span style="">Encouraging students to apply the concept of reported speech in their first language and compare the two.</span>
<span style="">Asking students to read a story at home and compare how characters speak with how their statements are quoted.</span>
<span style="">Asking students to share with the class what they discussed at dinner table at home the previous day.</span>
